channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: Chief Climate Negotiator Warns Against Consequences Of Leaving Paris Accord
item.description: May 31, 2017 - NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Todd Stern, former United States special envoy for climate change, about President Trump's likely withdrawal from the Paris climate accord. Stern led the negotiations for this deal.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Todd Stern, former United States special envoy for climate change, about President Trump's likely withdrawal from the Paris climate accord. Stern led the negotiations for this deal. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/31/530929878/chief-climate-negotiator-warns-against-consequences-of-leaving-paris-accord

item.title: Scientists Urge Governments To Protect Coral Reefs From Climate Change
item.description: May 31, 2017 - A paper published in Nature by the world's top scientists says climate change is making irreversible changes to the world's coral reefs, and the role before governments is to steer coral reefs in a way that maintains their biological functions.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - A paper published in Nature by the world's top scientists says climate change is making irreversible changes to the world's coral reefs, and the role before governments is to steer coral reefs in a way that maintains their biological functions. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/31/530929922/scientists-urge-governments-to-protect-coral-reefs-from-climate-change

item.title: President Trump Expected To Make Decision On Paris Climate Accord
item.description: May 31, 2017 - President Trump is expected to make a decision regarding whether or not the U.S. will pull out of the Paris climate accord. NPR takes a look at the potential political and environmental impacts of leaving the agreement.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - President Trump is expected to make a decision regarding whether or not the U.S. will pull out of the Paris climate accord. NPR takes a look at the potential political and environmental impacts of leaving the agreement. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/31/530929869/president-trump-expected-to-make-decision-on-paris-climate-accord

item.title: NASA Plans To Launch A Probe Next Year To 'Touch The Sun'
item.description: May 31, 2017 - The small spacecraft is set to hurtle toward the sun at about 450,000 miles per hour. Scientists hope it will clear up some big mysteries, such as why the sun's atmosphere is hotter than its surface.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - The small spacecraft is set to hurtle toward the sun at about 450,000 miles per hour. Scientists hope it will clear up some big mysteries, such as why the sun's atmosphere is hotter than its surface. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/31/530743287/nasa-plans-to-launch-a-probe-next-year-to-touch-the-sun

item.title: Shareholders Push Exxon To Disclose Business Impact Of Fighting Climate Change
item.description: May 31, 2017 - In a victory for environmental activists, investors have passed a nonbinding proposal calling for Exxon Mobil to publicly examine how efforts to cut greenhouse gases would affect its bottom line.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - In a victory for environmental activists, investors have passed a nonbinding proposal calling for Exxon Mobil to publicly examine how efforts to cut greenhouse gases would affect its bottom line. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/31/530904042/shareholders-push-exxon-to-disclose-business-impact-of-fighting-climate-change

item.title: 'Like Brain Boot Camp': Using Music To Ease Hearing Loss
item.description: May 31, 2017 - Researchers in Toronto are studying whether singing in a choir and practicing pitch can help hearing-impaired people function better in noisy environments.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - Researchers in Toronto are studying whether singing in a choir and practicing pitch can help hearing-impaired people function better in noisy environments. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/31/530723021/like-brain-boot-camp-using-music-to-ease-hearing-loss

item.title: Trump Has Multiple Escape Routes From Paris Climate Accord
item.description: May 31, 2017 - President Trump is nearing a decision on whether to pull out of the Paris climate agreement and has been meeting this week with competing voices in his Cabinet.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - President Trump is nearing a decision on whether to pull out of the Paris climate agreement and has been meeting this week with competing voices in his Cabinet. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/31/530890143/trump-has-multiple-escape-routes-from-paris-climate-accord

item.title: Total Failure: The World's Worst Video Game
item.description: May 31, 2017 - In the late summer of 1982, one man worked around the clock to program the video game version of Steven Spielberg's E.T. in just five weeks. The result wasn't pretty.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - In the late summer of 1982, one man worked around the clock to program the video game version of Steven Spielberg's E.T. in just five weeks. The result wasn't pretty. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/31/530235165/total-failure-the-worlds-worst-video-game

item.title: Activists Build Human Rights Abuse Cases With Help From Cellphone Videos
item.description: May 31, 2017 - A human rights group finds itself with an interesting problem — an overwhelming number of videos to catalog as it builds legal cases. Computer scientists are creating tools to analyze the videos.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - A human rights group finds itself with an interesting problem — an overwhelming number of videos to catalog as it builds legal cases. Computer scientists are creating tools to analyze the videos. http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/05/31/529825301/activists-build-human-rights-abuse-cases-with-help-from-cellphone-videos

item.title: College Art Professor Challenges Students To Build Insect Motels
item.description: May 30, 2017 - A concerned University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee art instructor challenged her students to construct insect motels out of natural, untreated materials. Each motel must provide an appropriate habitat for a particular insect and attract human interest too, as each has a QR Code with information about why that bug or bee matters in nature and needs to be nurtured. Nearly 100 are installed in a state park overlooking Lake Michigan in downtown Milwaukee.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

Nearly 100 are installed in a state park overlooking Lake Michigan in downtown Milwaukee. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/30/530769818/college-art-professor-challenges-students-to-build-insect-motels

item.title: Are State Rules For Treating Sepsis Really Saving Lives?
item.description: May 30, 2017 - Some states dictate how doctors must treat this life-threatening reaction to infection, and early intervention is helping. But scientific evidence may be changing too rapidly for the rules to keep up.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 30, 2017 - Some states dictate how doctors must treat this life-threatening reaction to infection, and early intervention is helping. But scientific evidence may be changing too rapidly for the rules to keep up. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/30/530224517/are-state-rules-for-treating-sepsis-really-saving-lives

item.title: How A Theory Of Crime And Policing Was Born, And Went Terribly Wrong
item.description: May 29, 2017 - Decades ago, researchers introduced a new theory of policing. It's called "broken windows" and is seen by many as a cure-all for crime. But the idea is often used in ways its creators never intended.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 29, 2017 - Decades ago, researchers introduced a new theory of policing. It's called "broken windows" and is seen by many as a cure-all for crime. But the idea is often used in ways its creators never intended. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/29/530192364/how-a-theory-of-crime-and-policing-was-born-and-went-terribly-wrong

item.title: How An Interview With A Shark Researcher Wound Up Starring A Shark
item.description: May 29, 2017 - Why have dozens of great white sharks turned up around Southern California beaches recently? Finding the answer led to a close-up view of a baby great white shark — and the researcher who caught her.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 29, 2017 - Why have dozens of great white sharks turned up around Southern California beaches recently? Finding the answer led to a close-up view of a baby great white shark — and the researcher who caught her. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/29/530240481/how-an-interview-with-a-shark-researcher-wound-up-starring-a-shark

item.title: Handshake-Free Zones Target Spread Of Germs In The Hospital
item.description: May 29, 2017 - Hospital-acquired infections can be life-threatening, and unwashed hands are often to blame. One hospital in California thinks banishing handshakes could help reduce infections.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 29, 2017 - Hospital-acquired infections can be life-threatening, and unwashed hands are often to blame. One hospital in California thinks banishing handshakes could help reduce infections. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/29/529878742/handshake-free-zones-target-spread-of-germs-in-the-hospital

item.title: From NFL Player To Neurosurgeon: 'Why Can't I Do Both?'
item.description: May 28, 2017 - Myron Rolle talks about his long journey from playing football at Florida State University and joining the NFL to going to Harvard medical school to start his residency in neurosurgery.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 28, 2017 - Myron Rolle talks about his long journey from playing football at Florida State University and joining the NFL to going to Harvard medical school to start his residency in neurosurgery. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/28/530504767/from-nfl-player-to-neurosurgeon-why-cant-i-do-both
